moves.1. c4: My opponent chosed the English Opening. I feel that I have pretty good statistics against the English Opening.
moves.1... e5: I´m preferring to play e5 against c4.
moves.2. Nc3 Nf6 3. e4 Bc5 4. Nf3 Ng4: I´m threatening against the weak square f2.
moves.5. d4 exd4: In the opening I´m trying to look in the Game Data Base for improvements. That´s one of the advantages in Correspondence Chess, the possibility to look in databases.
moves.6. Nxd4 Nf6 7. Bg5: Threatening e5 in the next move.
moves.7... O-O: Castling kingside. Now can white win a piece with a pin. Or can he?
moves.12. Ne4 Rf5 13. Bd3 Bb4+ 14. Ned2 Qe7+: Trying to prevent White from castling.
moves.15. Be2 Rxf3: A positional sacrifice! Was rather intuitive.
moves.16. gxf3: Erasing whites pawn structure on the kingside.
moves.16... d5: Trying to develop my other pieces so fast as possible!
moves.17. cxd5 Bf5 18. a3 Ba5 19. b4 Bb6 20. N: Whites king is stuck in the center!
moves.23. Ra2: White is trying to overprotect the bishop at e2.
moves.23... Bg6 24. Kf1: Finally giving up the castling idea. It´s not fun for White now!
moves.24... Rd8 25. Qd4 Rxd5 26. Qc3 c6 27. f4: Overlooked that pin! Bad done of me.
moves.29... Bf7 30. Bxd5 Bxd5 31. Rc2 Kf8: I´m now down with approximately a rook but still has the better pawn structure and king safety!
A little trap. If the White queen is taking my knight on a4, then ...Qe1 checkmate!
moves.37... Qe1#: I was finally victorious! But look at the material balance, I´m down with approximately a Rook and a light piece! Interesting game!
